newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: FOCUS-BFE deal to boost BPI's network.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-BFE deal to boost BPI's network.

text.p: The planned purchase of state bank Banco de Fomento & Exterior (BFE) by Banco Portugues de Investimento (BPI) will enable BPI to broaden its retail network and cut costs, analysts said on Thursday.
It could be some time before the price that BPI will pay for the state's stake in BFE becomes known, official sources said.
"It will benefit greatly from acquiring BFE's extensive retail network -- Banco Borges & Irmao," said Pedro Assuncao, analyst with Lisbon broker Central Investimentos.
"It is another step that will boost concentration in Portuguese banking and will allow BPI to cut costs," he added.
It could be some time before the price that BPI will pay for the state's stake in BFE becomes known, official sources said.
BPI will become Portugal's fourth biggest banking group, combining its retail bank Banco Fonsecas & Burnay, Portugal's eighth biggest bank, with BFE's BBI, Portugal's ninth biggest.
A selection jury chose BPI as the only candidate to continue to the final phase of the privatisation of BFE because its proposal was "unarguably" the best, Finance Minister Antonio Sousa Franco said.
The other candidates were Banco Finantia, which was allied to Swiss Bank Corp, and Banco Nacional de Credito Imobiliario, controlled by cork magnate Americo Amorim.
The final phase in the privatisation will be the opening of the envelopes containing the value of the bid which has to be above 1,980 escudos per share.
In February the Finance Ministry rejected a bid by BPI which valued BFE at 152 billion escudos.
Mark Howard of Cascais-based Lloyds Bank Fund Managers said the jury would have considered BPI's previous experience in absorbing then state owned bank Banco Fonsecas & Burnay.
"This is a good deal for BPI, which was the only candidate with a proven capacity to turn a state bank around," he said.
BPI shares soared 5.2 percent to close at a new high for the year of 2,115 escudos, up 105, on Lisbon bourse.
"BPI could test higher levels, perhaps touching 2,150 escudos as the market reacts positively to its acquisition of BFE," said one dealer.
Another operator said: "It is likely that BPI will gain more ground as there is plenty of demand for the stock and there are no sellers."
Shares in BFE were suspended by the Financial Markets Committee on Thursday at 2,545 escudos ($16.6). It was not known when trade would start again.
